raw_text:
UK heading wrong way, says Howard
 
 Tony Blair has had the chance to tackle the problems facing Britain and has failed, Michael Howard has said.
 
 "Britain is heading in the wrong direction", the Conservative leader said in his New Year message. Mr Blair's government was a "bossy, interfering government that takes decisions that should be made by individuals," he added. But Labour's campaign spokesman Fraser Kemp responded: "Britain is working, don't let the Tories wreck it again". Mr Howard also paid tribute to the nation's character for its generous response to the Asian quake disaster. The catastrophe was overshadowing the hopes for the future at this usually positive time of the year, Mr Howard said.
 
 "We watched the scenes of destruction with a sense of disbelief. The scale, the speed, the ferocity of what happened on Boxing Day is difficult to grasp. "Yet Britain's response has shone a light on our nation's character. The last week has shown that the warm, caring heart of Britain beats as strong as ever." He went on to reflect on the values that "most Britons hold dear". Looking ahead to the coming general election, he pledged to "turn these beliefs into reality" and set out the choices he says are facing Britain. "How much tax do people want to pay? Who will give taxpayers value for money, the clean hospitals and good, disciplined schools they want? "Who can be trusted to get a grip on the disorder on our streets and the chaos in our immigration system?"
 
 Mr Blair has failed to tackle these problems, he claimed, saying he has the "wrong solution" to them.
 
 "The result is big government and higher taxes eroding incentives, undermining enterprise and denying people choice. "Worst of all, it is a government that has wasted people's money and failed to tackle the problems families face today." The Tories, he said, can cut crime and improve public services without asking people to pay more taxes. "We can have progress without losing what makes Britain great - its tolerance, the respect for the rule of law, the ability of everyone to fulfil their potential. "We simply need to change direction. The election will give Britain the chance to change." This is the record Mr Blair will have to defend in the coming months, he said, urging voters to hold him to account.
 
 But Labour spokesman Mr Kemp said: "It would be more appropriate for this message to come out on 1 April, not 1 January." "Let us never forget that when Michael Howard was in government Britain suffered mass unemployment, 15% interest rates, record home repossessions, and the introduction of the poll tax. "With Labour Britain is working. Rather than alluding to false promises Michael Howard should be starting 2005 with an apology to the British people for the misery that the government, of which he was a member, inflicted upon the country.
llama3.2:1b:
Michael Howard says Tony Blair's UK government has failed to tackle key problems such as crime, public services and immigration, which have worsened since his own time in office. He claims Britain is headed in the wrong direction due to "big government" and higher taxes eroding incentives. Howard also praises Labour's campaign for its focus on the nation's character and promises to turn these values into reality.

Labour spokesman Fraser Kemp disagrees, saying it would be more appropriate to address issues now rather than after the next election. He criticizes Howard's response as "false promises" and urges voters to hold him accountable.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair's government failed to tackle problems facing Britain, says Michael Howard. Mr Blair's bossy and interfering style took decisions away from individuals. Howard calls for change direction in election, promising to cut crime and improve services without increasing taxes. Labour spokesman Fraser Kemp responds that Howard's criticisms are hypocritical, pointing out his past role in a government that caused mass unemployment and other problems.
gemma2:2b: Michael Howard criticized Tony Blair's government, stating it has failed to address Britain's problems and led the nation in the wrong direction.  He highlighted the need for reduced taxes and more efficient public services. Mr. Howard also praised Britain's response to the Asian earthquake disaster. In contrast, Labour Party spokesman Fraser Kemp defended the current government's track record. He argued that Britain is progressing under Labour and criticized Mr. Howard's past policies.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK Prime Minister Tony Blair's government had been effective in dealing with problems facing Britain, but Conservative PM Mr Howard accused the Tories' failure to tackle issues like poverty and crime. He praised Britain's character for being generous to help people recover from disasters, such as the Boxing Day tsunami. He also emphasized Britain's tolerance, respect for law, and ability of everyone to achieve their potential.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair's government failed to address Britain's problems and faces voters in the upcoming general election, while Michael Howard praises the nation's character and pledges progress without increasing taxes.
qwen2.5:3b: UK heading wrong way, says Howard. Tony Blair's government is criticized as "bossy" and interfering. Howard praises Britain's response to Asian quake disaster but criticizes Labour's failings in tackling issues like rising crime rates, poor public services, and higher taxes. He argues that Tories can address these without increasing taxes, emphasizing values such as tolerance and respect for law. Kemp counters by criticizing Blair's record and suggesting that Howard should apologize for his government's past failures.
opencoder:1.5b: The text summarizes key issues facing Britain, and outlines how it has responded to confront these challenges. It highlights key values and beliefs shared by the people during the past few years, as well as the future plans that have been put forth by Mr Blair for the upcoming election.
smollm:1.7b: The UK heading wrong way, says Howard
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. The user provided a detailed passage about UK leaders and their policies, particularly focusing on Tony Blair and Michael Howard. 

First, I'll read through the text carefully. It seems like it's discussing the leadership of the UK, specifically mentioning two leaders: Tony Blair and Michael Howard. The main points include that Tony Blair has had opportunities to address problems but failed, while Michael Howard has praised Britain's character despite facing a tough time, especially due to an Asian earthquake.

I should identify the key elements here: the comparison between Blair and Howard's approaches, the issue with Blair's handling of policies (bossy, interfering government), the mention of Labour's response by supporting openness instead of closing, and the contrast in their responses regarding the economic crisis from 2008 to 2013 versus 2015.

I also notice that Blair is criticized for his "wrong solution," while Howard is praised for his emphasis on Britain's character. The text mentions specific issues like unemployment, interest rates, and home repossessions in 2008-2013, which are important context.

Now, I need to condense this into a summary without any extra information or explanations. So, I'll highlight the main points: Blair vs. Howard's approaches, Labour's support for economic openness, the issues of 2008-2013, and the current state in 2015. I should make sure not to include any opinions or predictions but just present the facts clearly.

I need to ensure that each key point is included: the comparison between their approaches, Blair's failure, Howard's positive outlook on the nation's character, the economic problems from 2008-2013, and Labour's stance. Also, mentioning the recent issues in 2015 like unemployment and interest rates is important.

I'll structure this summary by first stating who is taking charge and their approach, then contrasting it with Labour's positive response, followed by the specific economic issues of 2008-2013, and concluding with the current state of the government in 2015. I should keep each section brief to maintain conciseness.

Let me check if I missed any important details: Blair was criticized for his actions, Howard emphasized Britain's character despite the crisis, Labour supported economic openness over control, and both mentioned specific issues like unemployment in 2013. I think that covers all necessary points without adding extra information.

Finally, I'll make sure the language is straightforward and free of any unnecessary words to present only the key ideas as requested.
</think>

Tony Blair has been criticized for his handling of policies, while Michael Howard praised Britain's character despite a tough economic time. The government faced unemployment in 2013 and interest rates during that period. Labour emphasized economic openness rather than closing traditional control systems. In contrast, Blair was accused of using "bossy" decisions to avoid addressing current challenges, leading to poor outcomes.
tinyllama:1.1b: The UK heading in the wrong direction is described as "Britain is heading, don't let the Tories wrangle it again" by Michael Howard in his New Year message. The Conservative leader attributes Britain's generous response to the Asian quake disaster to the nation's character and suggests that these beliefs should be turned into reality in the upcoming general election. The UK's political landscape is described as undergoing a shift away from big government and higher taxes, leading to progress without compromising people's values or public services. Howard calls on voters to hold him accountable in April.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The text provided has been condensed and summarized to provide a short, concise explanation of main ideas and events. 

Output: Michael Howard failed to tackle Britain's problems during his time in government, leading to widespread unemployment, interest rates, home repossessions, and the introduction of the poll tax. Despite this, Britain is now moving forward under Tony Blair's leadership with a focus on progress. The UK heading in the wrong direction, according to Michael Howard, and Labour is working to make British values count for more in the upcoming election.
phi:2.7b: The text says that Prime Minister Tony Blair has failed to tackle Britain's problems and get its economy moving in the right direction. He accuses Labour of being a "bossy" and "interfering" government that is taking decisions that should be made by individuals. The Conservative leader also praises Britain's character for its generous response to the Asian earthquake disaster, but says it is overshadowed by the crisis. He pledges to give voters a choice between more taxes and more government, or lower taxes and better public services. He blames Labour's record of wasting money and failing to deal with crime, disorder and immigration, and calls on people to hold him accountable in the coming months. He also expresses regret for not delivering on his promises when he was in government.
orca-mini:3b: UK heading in the wrong direction, says Howard as Blair's government fails to tackle problems facing Britain and has failed to tackle them, Tory leader Michael Howard says.
hermes3:3b:
UK heading wrong direction, says Howard
Michael Howard claims Tony Blair failed to tackle problems in Britain, big govt and higher taxes eroding incentives, and Britain is going in wrong direction.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Conservative leader Michael Howard criticized Tony Blair's government and claimed Britain is headed in the wrong direction. However, he praised the nation's character and response to the Asian quake disaster. In his New Year message, Howard reflected on values Britons hold dear and looked ahead to the general election as an opportunity to turn those beliefs into reality. He accused Blair of failing to tackle problems and wasting money, stating that the Tories can improve public services without increasing taxes. Labour's campaign spokesman Fraser Kemp responded, reminding people of Britain's progress under Labour and questioning the timing of Howard's message.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Michael Howard criticized Tony Blair's government in his New Year message, claiming Britain is heading in the wrong direction under Labour's "bossy, interfering" leadership. He argued that Blair has failed to address key issues like taxation, public services, crime, and immigration, leading to wasted public money and diminished individual choice. Howard pledged that the Conservatives could improve public services and cut crime without raising taxes, offering voters a chance for change in the upcoming election. He also praised Britain's generosity in responding to the Asian tsunami disaster. Labour's Fraser Kemp dismissed Howard's claims, defending Labour's record and accusing the Conservatives of past economic failures, urging voters not to trust them again.
stablelm2:1.6b: Conservative leader Michael Howard says UK's heading in the wrong direction, citing Tony Blair's failed administration as bossy and interfering. Labour spokesman Fraser Kemp counters by stating that Britain is working despite possible disruptions. Howard pays tribute to nation's character amid recent devastation and asks how much tax people want to pay, among other pressing issues. Despite failures, Labour says it can change the course without asking people for more money.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Michael Howard, Conservative leader, criticized Tony Blair's government in his New Year message as "bossy and interfering," arguing it has led Britain astray by implementing big government and higher taxes, which undermine enterprise and choice. He praised the nation's response to the Asian quake disaster, highlighting its caring character. Howard pledged to address taxation and public service improvements without increasing taxes, emphasizing that Britain can maintain its values of tolerance, respect for the rule of law, and individual potential. He urged voters to hold Blair accountable for his government's policies, including mass unemployment, high interest rates, home repossessions, and the poll tax during Howard's tenure. In response, Labour spokesman Fraser Kemp countered that Britain is working well under their leadership, contrasting it with the misery caused by previous Conservative governments.
